messageBody:
On Mon, 3 Feb 2003, Manuel Amago wrote:

> For clarity's sake, let us imagine that your company uses its own cooked
> version of the Date class: MyDate. (Don't ask me why they'd do this,
> its just an example. :^) It is the company standard that you use this
> class anywhere where you would otherwise use the java API Date class.
> Thus, we can see the utility of having a reusable custom Assert class
> with different MyDate assert signatures, for use across different
> company projects.
>
> However, this custom class could never have been part of jUnit's Assert
> API, so how would you include these custom methods?
>
> (Examples of methods to include would be:
> void assertEquals(MyDate expected, MyDate actual);
> void assertEquals(String msg, MyDate expected, MyDate actual);
> void assertEquals(MyDate expected, MyDate actual, MyDate delta);
> void assertEquals(String msg, MyDate expected, MyDate actual, MyDate
> delta);
> )

I thought I'd explained this in the post that started this thread, but
perhaps I wasn't clear.

The TestCase has an assertEquals(Object, Object) method. You always call
this method for any comparison you do.

If you want to have a special comparison for a pair of MyDate objects,
you create a class that deals with this (with the interface I described
previously) and register it with the TestCase, using something like

Asserter myDateAsserter = ...
registerAssertion(myDateAsserter, MyDate.class);

Now when you invoke assertEquals(Object, Object) with a pair of objects
of class MyDate (or that inherit from MyDate, if you've not registered
another comparitor for the subclasses), the assertEquals method will
invoke the assert(Object, Object) method on your Asserter, rather than
using a default one.
